aws::graph::propositions: # Robinson Helicopter R-44 II Autorotation Accident Near Pahrump, Nevada
The accident involved a Robinson Helicopter Company R-44 II with registration N4246Z.
The accident occurred on August 24, 2014, at approximately 0650 Pacific daylight time.
The accident location was approximately 12 miles south of Pahrump, Nevada.
The helicopter was registered to CSC Trust Company of Delaware Trustee.
The helicopter was operated by the pilot under Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The pilot held a commercial pilot license.
The pilot sustained minor injuries in the accident.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time of the accident.
No flight plan was filed for the local personal flight.
The flight departed from North Las Vegas Airport in Las Vegas, Nevada at approximately 0605.
The defining event of the accident was a total loss of engine power.
The pilot reported a total loss of engine power at approximately 3,500 feet above ground level.
The engine power loss occurred while the pilot was rolling back the throttle for a practice autorotation.
The pilot stated the throttle was rolled back smoothly.
The pilot stated the throttle was rolled back only enough for a small tachometer needle separation.
The pilot made several unsuccessful attempts to restart the engine.
Unable to restart the engine, the pilot performed an autorotation emergency landing.
During landing, the helicopter slid forward approximately 20 feet.
The helicopter's skids dug into the dry lake bed.
The helicopter nosed over after the skids dug into the dry lake bed.
The main rotor blades impacted the ground after the helicopter nosed over.
The helicopter rolled onto its right side after the main rotor blades impacted the ground.
A Federal Aviation Administration inspector examined the helicopter wreckage.
The main rotor blades were substantially damaged.
The tail boom was substantially damaged.
Fuel was observed leaking from both tanks at the accident site.
According to the pilot, the fuel tank quantities were approximately 7/8 full just prior to the accident.
The helicopter was recovered to a secure storage facility for further examination.
The National Transportation Safety Board investigator-in-charge examined the helicopter.
A Robinson Helicopter investigator examined the helicopter.
No evidence of any internal damage to the fuel injected engine was observed during examination.
No evidence of any internal damage to the engine accessories was observed during examination.
The oil dipstick reading indicated a normal quantity.
Continuity with all the engine controls was established during examination.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| | |
|-|-|
| Autorotation | Loss of engine power (total) (Defining event) |
| Landing-landing roll | Nose over/nose down |

On August 24, 2014, about 0650 Pacific daylight time, a Robinson Helicopter Company, R-44 II, N4246Z, sustained substantial damage while practicing an emergency autorotation, about 12 miles south of Pahrump, Nevada. The helicopter was registered to CSC Trust Company of Delaware Trustee and operated by the pilot under the provisions of Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91. The commercial pilot sustained minor injuries. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed and no flight plan was filed for the local personal flight that departed North Las Vegas Airport (VGT), Las Vegas, Nevada, about 0605.

The pilot reported a total loss of engine power at about 3,500 feet, above ground level, while rolling the throttle back for a practice autorotation. He stated the throttle was rolled back smoothly and only enough required for a small tachometer needle separation. Subsequently, the pilot made several unsuccessful attempts to restart the engine. Unable to restart the engine, the pilot performed an autorotation emergency landing. The pilot further reported that during landing, the helicopter slid forward about 20 feet; at that point, the skids dug into the dry lake bed and the helicopter nosed over. Subsequently, the main rotor blades impacted the ground, and the helicopter rolled onto its right side.

Examination of the helicopter wreckage by a Federal Aviation Administration inspector revealed that the main rotor blades and tail boom were substantially damaged. Additionally, fuel was observed leaking from both tanks at the site. According to the pilot, the fuel tank quantities were about 7/8's full just prior to the accident. The helicopter was recovered to a secure storage facility for further examination.

Further examination of the helicopter by the National Transportation Safety Board investigator-in-charge and a Robinson Helicopter investigator revealed no evidence of any internal damage to the fuel injected engine or its accessories was observed. The oil dipstick reading indicated a normal quantity. Continuity with all the engine controls was established.
